comments: Terms are pairwise coprime with very high probability. I didn't find terms which are pairwise noncoprime, although it may be a case of the "strong law of small numbers." - Daniel Forgues, Apr 23 2012
links: Harry J. Smith, Table of n, a(n) for n=0,...,100
Hisanori Mishima, WIFC (World Integer Factorization Center): PI Pn + NextPrime (n = 1 to 100), PI Pn - NextPrime (n = 1 to 100), PI Pn + 1 (n = 1 to 100), PI Pn - 1 (n = 1 to 100).
mathematica: Module[{nn=20,pr},pr=Prime[Range[nn+1]];Join[{3},FoldList[ Times,Most[ pr]] + Rest[pr]]] (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Feb 19 2016 *)
prog: (PARI) { n=-1; m=1; forprime (p=2, prime(101), write("b060881.txt", n++, " ", m + p); m*=p; ) } [From _Harry J. Smith_, Jul 19 2009]
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, May 05 2001
